messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Hardness of Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search under L-infinity

Paper Abstract: Abstract We show conditional hardness of Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search (ANN) under the ‚Ñì‚àûsubscript‚Ñì\ell_{\infty} norm with two simple reductions. Our first reduction shows that hardness of a special case of the Shortest Vector Problem (SVP), which captures many provably hard instances of SVP, implies a lower bound for ANN with polynomial preprocessing time under the same norm. Combined with a recent quantitative hardness result on SVP under ‚Ñì‚àûsubscript‚Ñì\ell_{\infty} (Bennett et al., FOCS 2017), our reduction implies that finding a (1+Œµ)1ùúÄ(1+\varepsilon)-approximate nearest neighbor under ‚Ñì‚àûsubscript‚Ñì\ell_{\infty} with polynomial preprocessing requires near-linear query time, unless the Strong Exponential Time Hypothesis (SETH) is false. This complements the results of Rubinstein (STOC 2018), who showed hardness of ANN under ‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1}, ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}, and edit distance. Further improving the approximation factor for hardness, we show that, assuming SETH, near-linear query time is required for any approximation factor less than 333 under ‚Ñì‚àûsubscript‚Ñì\ell_{\infty}. This shows a conditional separation between ANN under the ‚Ñì1/‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{1}/\ell_{2} norm and the ‚Ñì‚àûsubscript‚Ñì\ell_{\infty} norm since there are sublinear time algorithms achieving better than 333-approximation for the ‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1} and ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2} norm. Lastly, we show that the approximation factor of 333 is a barrier for any naive gadget reduction from the Orthogonal Vectors problem.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Hardness of Nearest Neighbor under L-infinity",
        "Fine-grained hardness of CVP(P) ‚Äì Everything that we can prove (and nothing else)",
        "Near-optimal hashing algorithms for approximate nearest neighbor in high dimensions",
        "Approximate nearest neighbor search in high dimensions",
        "The shortest vector problem in L22{}_{ extrm{2}} is NP-hard for randomized reductions (extended abstract)",
        "Status Report on the Second Round of the NIST Post-Quantum Cryptography Standardization Process",
        "Improved Algorithms for the Shortest Vector Problem and the Closest Vector Problem in the Infinity Norm",
        "Optimal Hashing-based Time-Space Trade-offs for Approximate Near Neighbors",
        "Approximate near neighbors for general symmetric norms",
        "Lattice problems in NP intersect coNP",
        "Optimal Data-Dependent Hashing for Approximate Near Neighbors",
        "Distributed PCP Theorems for Hardness of Approximation in P",
        "New directions in nearest neighbor searching with applications to lattice sieving",
        "On the Quantitative Hardness of CVP",
        "Speeding-up lattice sieving without increasing the memory, using sub-quadratic nearest neighbor search",
        "Semi-Direct Sum Theorem and Nearest Neighbor under l_infty",
        "Another np-complete problem and the complexity of computing short vectors in a lattice",
        "Static data structure lower bounds imply rigidity",
        "Approximating SVP-infinity to within almost-polynomial factors is NP-hard",
        "CRYSTALS-Dilithium: A Lattice-Based Digital Signature Scheme",
        "Combining fuzzy information from multiple systems (extended abstract)",
        "Combining Fuzzy Information from Multiple Systems",
        "Tensor-based hardness of the shortest vector problem to within almost polynomial factors",
        "Approximate nearest neighbors: towards removing the curse of dimensionality",
        "On Approximate Nearest Neighbors under L-infinity Norm",
        "Better algorithms for high-dimensional proximity problems via asymmetric embeddings",
        "The Complexity of k-SAT",
        "Which Problems Have Strongly Exponential Complexity?",
        "Extensions of Lipschitz mappings into a Hilbert space",
        "Hardness of approximating the shortest vector problem in lattices",
        "Inapproximability Results for Computational Problems on Lattices",
        "Two algorithms for nearest-neighbor search in high dimensions",
        "Sieving for Shortest Vectors in Lattices Using Angular Locality-Sensitive Hashing",
        "On the distortion required for embedding finite metric spaces into normed spaces",
        "Complexity of Lattice Problems: A Cryptographic Perspective",
        "The Shortest Vector in a Lattice is Hard to Approximate to within Some Constant",
        "Lower Bounds on Near Neighbor Search via Metric Expansion",
        "On lattices, learning with errors, random linear codes, and cryptography",
        "Lattice problems and norm embeddings",
        "Hardness of approximate nearest neighbor search",
        "Nearest-Neighbor Methods in Learning and Vision: Theory and Practice",
        "Finding Correlations in Subquadratic Time, with Applications to Learning Parities and the Closest Pair Problem",
        "A new algorithm for optimal 2-constraint satisfaction and its implications",
        "Algorithms and resource requirements for fundamental problems",
        "On some fine-grained questions in algorithms and complexity",
        "Subcubic Equivalences Between Path, Matrix, and Triangle Problems",
        "Some Complexity Questions Related to Distributive Computing"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Hardness of Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search under L-infinity, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
